abstract: Cutting costs and eliminating huge legal bills have helped the bank, but its rivals are ahead on efficiency, among other areas.
snippet: Cutting costs and eliminating huge legal bills have helped the bank, but its rivals are ahead on efficiency, among other areas.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo and JPMorgan have reported third-quarter results that highlight a $7 billion challenge for rival Bank of America. That’s the extra annual profit the lender run by Brian Moynihan would need to earn for a 10 percent return on equity, generally the level at which big banks cover their cost of capital. Cutting spending to match Wells Fargo’s efficient operation would not quite suffice, though. And JPMorgan proved on Tuesday that it can manage passable results even when revenue falls.

headline.main: Bank of America’s Hunt for Growth
